content.description: This has difficult moves at the start.
content.protection:
Bolts to an anchor shared with

Gone Walkabout

.
content.location:
Climb the right side of arete just right of

Gone Walkabout

.

Per

rob bauer

: this is the 4th line of bolts from the left.

content.description: When the climbing gets easier near the top, be aware of large block on the arete. Removing it would probably take out the telephone pole below.
content.protection: 6 bolts to a 2-bolt anchor with chains.
content.location: Climb colorful green arete just right of rappel anchors very close to tree leaning against the wall.

content.description: This pleasant climb passes the Sisyphus Boulder on the right near the top. It has several impressive letterbox holds.
content.protection: 6 bolts to a shared anchor with other routes.
content.location:
Begin just right of

Don't Touch This

at an overhang right off the ground.

climbs.name: Permit This
climbs.fa: Brian Parsons, Greg Hand, and Paul Heyliger

content.description:
This is on Upper Oz.

It looks like a very wide stem from below, but you never even try once you start. Everything shows up when you need it. This has a semi-powerful start, walk the ramp and climb the clever headwall inside the acute corner up to the chains.

Rap the route.

(I like the name, since we all felt like that when they announced the new route guidelines for the canyon.)
content.location:
This is the 2nd climb from the left after you step around the corner from pitch 1 of

Finding Nemo

/

Finding Dory

.

content.description: This is the longest route at Upper Oz. It climbs up the left side of the fin and then moves around to the right at the top. The anchors are set back a bit, so you can't really see your partner if you belay up top (am I the only one who does that? Actually, I lowered, and it worked out ok). Big holds, lots of bolts, and good exposure equals fun. There's a few friable edges at this time, but they will clean up with a little more traffic.
content.location:
This is on Upper Oz.

This is currently the right-most route and climbs an obvious tall feature near the middle of this entire ledge. It starts in broken reddish-brown layers, moves up onto a grey slab, goes over right onto the side of the fin, and finally joins the main arete near the top.

Rap off.

content.description:
This is yet another not-my-route with interesting climbing from the bottom to the anchors that made it worthwhile for me.

(BTW, if you've never posted a route, they ask you in this section to say where the crux is; what's interesting; what are our deepest thoughts...). I would never give it away like that or tell you what to do. It's safe enough, go see what you think!
content.location:
It is on Upper Oz.

This is the third route from the left and climbs just inside the obvious column on the right leg of the acute alcove corner. The first several bolts you see on the outside are actually a harder variation, so look left just inside to see bolts leading up the the roof where you pop out and join up with those obvious bolts.

content.description:
Finding Nemo is an OK route with 2 short pitches, though it may be climbed as one. It is also a way to the Upper Oz area. The anchors at the mid-station are hanging chains, just out of reach off the ledge and are shared with

Finding Dory

. If going to Upper Oz, just get off here, and go right around the corner. The second pitch continues up left to the anchor chains.

Rap' the route in 2 drops with a single rope.
content.location: After you follow directions to the "heavily guyed telephone pole" and wade through the scrub to the wall on the right of the huge block, just above the telephone pole guy wires, you should see two bolt routes heading up the dark stone. This is the left route.

content.description:
This is another interesting bolt protected 5.5 that can be climbed in 1 or 2 pitches. It is the right-hand route on Lower Oz and may be used to access Upper Oz or enjoyed for itself.

It shares the the anchors with

Finding Nemo

and is maybe a bit more physical than

'Nemo

. P1 is ~75', and P2 is ~65'.

Rappel in 2 drops with one rope.
content.location: Follow directions up right from the telephone pole to the dark face on the right, across from Carbage.  This route is on the right and shares anchors with the climb on the left.

content.description:
This is the easiest route on Upper Oz. It is safe and fun.

Watch for the interesting rock-bolted-to-the-wall up by the anchor (yeah, right where you fight through the vegetation). It shares an anchor with the route to the left.

Rappel.
content.location: This is currently the 5th or 6th route from the left, or second from the right.

content.description:
This seemed harder than 10c to me. After you get passed the 2nd bolt, the grade eases a lot. There are clever changes of direction, and maybe you need a stick clip?

There is a boulder near the top that was apparently nerve-wracking enough to require being bolted with chain to the wall!  You don't see that every day.
content.location:
This is on the left side of the next feature downhill to the right. You'll easily spot at least 2 of the 3 routes on this smooth rock, this is the leftmost.

Rap the route.
